channel.title: Nooby question
channel.description:
If you're going to flame me because of the previous question, no I didn't look at all the files lol.. It gives this error on the run_lserver :
[code]runls: [java] Login Server starting up... [java] Unknown database 'rscd' [java] java.lang.Exception: Unable to connect to MySQL [java] at org.rscdaemon.ls.net.DatabaseConnection.<init>(DatabaseConnec tion.java:50) [java] at org.rscdaemon.ls.Server.main(Server.java:191) [java] Java Result: 1
BUILD SUCCESSFUL Total time: 1 second[/code]
Help please? Thank you.
I have a SQL server on my computer, do I need to set the config to use my computer as the sql and ls server or what?

item.title: Nooby question
item.dc:creator: @freaky5000 freaky5000
item.description:
@freaky5000 wrote:

Problem solution should be:

go into your phpmyadmin, make sure you sql database is uploaded, and the name of the database is exactly rscd. Should indefanatly fix it… If it doesnt work, this is most likely because you have just uploaded the sql file instead of creating a database name and inserting the file into the database.

Read full topic

item.title: Nooby question
item.dc:creator: @Sean Sean
item.description:
@Sean wrote:

The programming style of c vs java is barely comparable in alot of areas. Theres being able to program in a language, then being able to program well in that language. Especially since c is in not oo, the code you will be producing will probably make the majority of java developers balk.

However, since you have said you are used to c, then skip straight to effective java (its basicallys a pitfalls/good practice guide, I dont know any developer that has read it and said it was a waste of time). Since you come from a strong c background, your design pattern knowledge may be limited, so that part is still good advice.

And regards to how many rsc sources there are, if you dont like what you are using - roll your own. When I share code I hope that people learn from it, rather than hack at it and not understand what is going on. I know it may be daunting to start from nothing and get somewhere, and you have to in some cases answer some tough design questions that may or may not bite you in the ass down the line depending on your knowledge of the problem domain… but its where the true fun lies.

Read full topic

item.title: Nooby question
item.dc:creator: @Vrunk Vrunk
item.description:
@Vrunk wrote:

[quote=“petrock6, post:9, topic:218328”]I’ve programmed before.
I know Perl, and C code, html [I don’t think it’s a programming language] but I know that C is VERY RELATED to Java.
It isn’t like I haven’t programmed before.

  • Thanks Pjers, I’ll try that.[/quote]

I’d have to disagree with that because of one major issue…

Java has garbage collection, C does not.

If you want something that is similar to Java, then C# is your best bet.

Read full topic

item.title: Nooby question
item.dc:creator: @Ch3rry Ch3rry
item.description:
@Ch3rry wrote:

[quote=“Sean, post:7, topic:218328”]The problem is that you have the dreams and aspirations to code / modify a server. This is great, but may I just say this.

Read, read up on programming, theres alot to it and unless you only want to be able to innovate minute things and even then require assitance at every step. I would recommend these books if you want to go down the java line. Java - how to program or Head first java. Follow this up with effective java and a book of your choice on design patterns (head first design patterns would probably be good for you).

I know that you want to do mad cool hax and stuff, and reading books can be a slow process, but you can do it in parallel, learn what you can about programming, how to do stuff, how to structure your code and create reusable flexible designs and use this knowledge in your server as you continue.

These books can all be found in various places around the internet. Ebooks are free, knowledge is free on the internet. Go teach yourself.[/quote]
Holy shit! Someone on this forum actually has useful tips instead of sarcasm? Need a lot more people like you around here bro.

Read full topic
